description: A program by Phil Donahue about human beings exploring why humans act in certain ways and whether people can change their behaviors. Themes of the program include gender roles, the family, education, and marriage. The program begins with a discussion of the biological differences between men and women and an interview with Dr. June Reinisch of the Kinsey Institute. The program continues with a discussion of the differences between men and women's brains and cognitive ability. Part two focuses on the role of marriage and the family in society. Seidenberg was a psychiatrist who was one of the first to fight for the removal of homosexuality as a disorder from the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. He was a writer and speaker on the subject of prescribing and marketing of psychiatric drugs to women as well as on other topics. Karen DeCrow was the literary executor of partner and collaborator Dr. Robert Seidenberg’s estate.

description: Karen DeCrow participates in a panel focused on International Protection for Women's rights. The panel was part of the National NOW conference in Buffalo, New York and discussed eliminating all forms of discrimination against women, the nature of international law, and its enforcement. DeCrow presents a suggestion for a foreign policy initiative making the status of women a focus of the 1988 Presidential Election.

description: Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment at the University of Tulsa. The debate was sponsored by the Student Association of the University of Tulsa. Schlafly presents her argument first and then DeCrow speaks. Questions are taken from the audience. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: WWWE radio 11 of Cleveland, Ohio broadcast. After the local news report, Merle Pollis interviews Karen DeCrow about an upcoming vote in Ohio to restrict the sale of pornography in stores like Lawson's. DeCrow shares her stance that this is a threat to the First Amendment. Lawson's was later sued by the American Family Association, after a Dairy Mart manager in Ohio complained that the company's policy of selling pornography subjected her to sexual and religious harassment. The court case, Stanley v. Lawson Co., was seen as a test of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. The court ultimately ruled in favor of Lawson.

description: Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment at Syracuse University. The debate was sponsored by the Women's Law Caucus of Syracuse University and the Greater Syracuse Chapter of NOW. DeCrow presents her argument first, then Schlafly speaks, and then there is time for rebuttal. Questions are taken from the audience. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: Karen DeCrow and Dr. Robert Seidenberg facilitate a workshop about Feminist Challenge: New Psychiatric Labels at the 20th Annual NOW Conference in Denver, Colorado. The workshop focuses on the idea that social conditions are now being labeled and treated as diseases and that this is a feminist issue. DeCrow begins the workshop with an introduction, Seidenberg presents a slideshow, and then discussion by the workshop attendees. Seidenberg was a psychiatrist who was one of the first to fight for the removal of homosexuality as a disorder from the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. He was a writer and speaker on the subject of prescribing and marketing of psychiatric drugs to women as well as on other topics.

description: Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment on the televised program called Richard Hogue Weekdays. Hogue structures the debate around the topics of education, government power, military, employment, and family. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: The debate between DeCrow-Schlafly continues as both speakers respond to questions from the audience. Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment at Syracuse University. The debate was sponsored by the Women's Law Caucus of Syracuse University and the Greater Syracuse Chapter of NOW. DeCrow presents her argument first, then Schlafly speaks, and then there is time for rebuttal. Questions are taken from the audience. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: Karen DeCrow speaks at a workshop called Paying the Bill: Effective Fundraising at the 1990 NOW Conference, NOW90, in San Francisco, California. description: Karen DeCrow speaks to the National Congress for Men in Detroit, Michigan about equality for the sexes. DeCrow felt very strongly that absolute gender equality should be the goal of the women's movement. Because of this, she often argued for policies and defended clients with which her peers would disagree. She spoke at the 1982 National Congress of Men and was a proponent of father's rights and joint custody in divorce proceedings. She was against women-only spaces just as much as men-only spaces.

description: Robert Seidenberg and Karen DeCrow speak at the 20th anniversary NOW salon. Seidenberg was a psychiatrist who was one of the first to fight for the removal of homosexuality as a disorder from the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. He was a writer and speaker on the subject of prescribing and marketing of psychiatric drugs to women as well as on other topics. Karen DeCrow was the literary executor of partner and collaborator Dr. Robert Seidenberg’s estate.

description: Karen DeCrow's 49th birthday party. Guests representing various committees report on plans for DeCrow's 50th birthday celebration, a play on DeCrow's meetings as president of the National Organization for Women (NOW). DeCrow was elected the fourth president of NOW in 1974. She served two terms, getting re-elected under a Majority Caucus platform in 1975, which emphasized support for all women, including women of color and non-heterosexual women, as well as advocating for repeal of anti-abortion laws. At this time, many NOW members felt that including race in its platform, as well as controversial issues such as gay rights and abortion, was distracting from the main equality message. Others, including DeCrow, felt that ignoring any existing inequalities within society, even within the membership of NOW, was against the ideals of an organization meant to promote equality. As president, DeCrow raised public awareness of NOW further by being the organization’s first president to be invited to the White House. NOW under DeCrow’s presidency led boycotts against states that chose not to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA), helped defeat proposed limits on Title IX, held the first “Take Back the Night” march against violence against women, started multiple task forces, settled major employment discrimination lawsuits, and more.

description: Karen DeCrow and Dr. Robert Seidenberg facilitate a workshop about Feminist Challenge: New Psychiatric Labels at the 20th Annual NOW Conference in Denver, Colorado. The workshop focuses on the idea that social conditions are now being labeled and treated as diseases and that this is a feminist issue. DeCrow begins the workshop with an introduction, Seidenberg presents a slideshow, and then discussion by the workshop attendees. Seidenberg was a psychiatrist who was one of the first to fight for the removal of homosexuality as a disorder from the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. He was a writer and speaker on the subject of prescribing and marketing of psychiatric drugs to women as well as on other topics.

description: Karen DeCrow speaks at the National NOW conference in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. DeCrow's workshop focuses on fighting discrimination, and she discusses the glass ceiling and equal pay in terms of cases that she litigated. DeCrow was elected the fourth president of NOW in 1974. She served two terms, getting re-elected under a Majority Caucus platform in 1975, which emphasized support for all women, including women of color and non-heterosexual women, as well as advocating for repeal of anti-abortion laws. At this time, many NOW members felt that including race in its platform, as well as controversial issues such as gay rights and abortion, was distracting from the main equality message. Others, including DeCrow, felt that ignoring any existing inequalities within society, even within the membership of NOW, was against the ideals of an organization meant to promote equality. As president, DeCrow raised public awareness of NOW further by being the organization’s first president to be invited to the White House. description: Ed Asner is interviewed for the program "The Lives of Men." Asner served on the board of a group called the Coalition of Free Men (now the National Coalition for Men). During the interview, Asner discusses how gender-based roles limit men legally, socially, and emotionally. Asner also talks about how the women's liberation movement frees women, but also frees men.
